title: Teaching
text: I teach several courses at Case Western Reserve University.

title: Teaching
section: MPHP 650: Public Health Practicum (Fall, Spring, Summer)
text:
MPHP 650: Public Health Practicum (Fall, Spring, Summer)
The Public Health Practicum is an integral component of the MPH curriculum, allowing students to apply, develop, and refine their conceptual knowledge and skills as part of a planned, supervised, and evaluated community-based experience. The Practicum is designed to move students beyond the walls of academia, to understand the political, economic, social, and organizational contexts within which public health activities are conducted.

title: Teaching
section: MPHP 652: Public Health Capstone (Fall, Spring, Summer)
text:
MPHP 652: Public Health Capstone (Fall, Spring, Summer)
The Public Health Capstone provides students with the opportunity to apply the knowledge and skills acquired through their Master of Public Health academic program to a problem involving the health of the community. Students will learn to communicate with target groups in an effective manner; to identify ethical, social, and cultural issues relating to public health policies, research, and interventions; to identify the process by which decisions are made within the agency or organization; and to identify and coordinate use of resources at the placement site. The Capstone Essay represents the culminating experience required for the degree program and may take the form of a research thesis, an evaluation study, or an intervention study. Each student is required to formally present the experience and research findings.

title: Teaching
text:
Notes
In addition to the courses above, I also lead or co-lead variations of these experiential learning courses for select dual degree programs. These include an undergraduate capstone course listing (MPHP 653) and integrated social work + public health practicum and capstone courses (MPHP 655, 656, and 657).

title: Teaching
text:
MPHP 101: Introduction to Public Health (Spring)
MPHP 101 is a large, undergraduate course required for the minor in public health in the Department of Population & Quantiative Health Sciences. The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the science and art of public health through understanding historical and current issues through public health case histories and controversies. Students are introduced to social, behavioral, cultural, and environmental influences on population health. Emphasis is placed on social justice as a central component of public health, with an overview of health inequity and commitment to vulnerable populations. Core public health practices relating to health promotion program design, community assessment and improvement planning, health communication, health policy and enforcement, and health behavior change are featured. The course promotes understanding of health care and public health systems domestically and globally, including preparedness for and response to public health emergencies.

title: Teaching
text:
PAST 451 Introduction to Public Health (Summer)
This course introduces Physician Assistant students to concepts of public health and provide experience in public health by completion of a project. The course is a relatively broad overview of the field, but focuses on 1) the intersection of public health and clinical care, and 2) public health topics that are particularly relevant in Cleveland.

title: Teaching
section: Community Health Research & Practice (CHRP) seminar (Fall and Spring)
text:
Community Health Research & Practice (CHRP) seminar (Fall and Spring)
The Community Health Research & Practice (CHRP) seminar is held weekly and is open to all MPH students. While topics vary each week throughout the semester, the seminar has four main goals: 1) to support Master of Public Health (MPH) students as they develop and complete their Practicum experiences and Capstone projects, 2) to provide support in the development and submission of peer-reviewed presentations and publications, 3) to provide a forum for dissemination of innovations in public health practice and research, and 4) to provide a forum for networking among public health students and professionals. The CHRP seminar acts as the classroom component of community-based experiential learning requirements of the MPH program.

title: Curriculum vitae
text:

View the tutorial for this template (+ download link)

title: Hello! My name is Andrew Morris. Welcome to my website.
text:
LinkedIn
  
  
    
     Email
  




Hello! My name is Andrew Morris. Welcome to my website.
I am the Assistant Director of the Master of Public Health (MPH) program at Case Western Reserve University. Our program is housed in the School of Medicine, Department of Population & Quantitative Health Sciences. In this position I guide students through community-based research and practice experiences, serve as a liaison for community partners and alumni, and am actively involved with academic program management, curriculum development, program accreditation, and student support.
I have an undergraduate background in biology and psychology. I studied at Ohio University in Athens, Ohio and it was here that I discovered an interest in public health through community and campus involvement. I developed a particular interest in housing and the built environment as a determinant of health through my involvement with the OU chapter of Habitat for Humanity. Upon graduation I completed a summer-long bicycle trip from Portland, Maine to Santa Barbara, California for the affordable housing cause. Our team raised thousands of dollars for local Habitat affiliates and other affordable housing organizations and stopped to build with local affordable housing efforts on 12 occasions.
In 2012, I moved to Greater Cleveland to begin studying public health at Case Western Reserve. While an MPH student at CWRU, I worked as an AmeriCorps member with the Ohio Association of Community Health Centers. I was based at Neighborhood Family Practice, a federally qualified health center on Cleveland’s west side, where I served as a patient advocate. Upon the conclusion of my AmeriCorps service and graduation from the MPH program, I remained at Neighborhood Family Practice where I served as the interim coordinator of the refugee screening program, and later as the manager of a school-based health program. I transitioned to CWRU in 2017 and now serve as the program’s Assistant Director.
I am actively involved with national public health and academic organizations, including the American Public Health Association (APHA), the Association of Schools & Programs of Public Health (ASPPH), Ohio Public Health Association (OPHA), and the Association for Prevention Teaching & Research (APTR).
I teach several courses at CWRU, including Public Health Practicum, Public Health Capstone, and lead a weekly Community Health Research & Practice (CHRP) seminar. Outside the MPH program, I teach a large undergraduate Public Health 101 course in the department and I teach Introduction to Public Health in the Physician Assistant program.
On this website, you will find a bit about my work at CWRU and beyond.
Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions or would like to collaborate.

I have served as a capstone advisory committee member for 59 students to date.
